With what operative models, local and imported, does the Latin American plastic artist face his circumstances; and, with what sorts of critical feedback is he faced?- Part 2 - English Annotation

People
Picasso, Pablo, 1881-1973
Lam, Wifredo
Tamayo, Rufino, 1899-1991

00:32

Modern art was born as a break from local cultures, through the incorporation and revaluation of the aesthetic values of so-called primitive cultures, whose artistic value had been hidden under the veil of anthropological phenomena. Thus, if it is valid for Picasso to incorporate elements of African art into his work, it is also valid that Wifredo Lam or Rufino Tamayo reveal and revalue in their own work certain aspects of the original aesthetics of our countries. This is not the same as the theoretical aberration suffered by most Mexican muralists of the 1920s and 1930s, who attempted a prefabricated project of national identity-seeking.

People
Paz, Octavio, 1914-1998

03:23

I donât see how contemporary art can exist without the use and method of contemporary technology. We must also keep in mind that art is always an ideology. Action painting, pop art, superrealism, and many other forms that artists from highly industrialized countries have used as a way to criticize their society are not valid for the Latin American artist. As Octavio Paz said, "It is not possible for him to rebel against something that has not happened to him." On the contrary, our societies are run with a paternalistic mindset, improvised, and disorganized.

People
Stalin, Joseph, 1878-1953
Hitler, Adolf, 1889-1945

04:08

Perhaps that is why art with a constructive senseâart that shows great rigor in its creationâis a phenomenon that has already become a tradition in our countries. From Argentina to Mexico, we find values or movements that reflect this phenomenon. I do not consider it valid to diminish the semantic value of this type of expression. If it were true that it is not a highly communicative language with a clear ideology, it would not be understandable why it was so viciously repressed, as Constructivism was in Stalinâs Russia or the Bauhaus in Hitlerâs Germany.

People

I want to emphasize that this is precisely what it is about, in the interpretation of artâthe distracted gaze of the spectator, who does not know how to resolve, who does not know how to enter into this language that is visual art. From there comes all this kind of incursions into other fields, influences from other fields, like theater, like literature, like poetry, in order to try to make that interpretation.

People

People
GÃ³ngora, Leonel

12:31

GÃ³ngora began by saying, apologizing that he was a painter and could not speak like a literate person. He was amazed by the ease with which the literati use words, but I believe that the literati also sin by the excessive use of words and everything becomes very vague. I think that what GÃ³ngora said as an artist was not just rambling, as he tried to excuse himself, but that he said very coherent things, and I believe we respect greatly his passion, as he says, of an artist who wants to see and who wants others to also see his very secret work.

People
GÃ³ngora, Leonel
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016

13:09

However, I had to cut it off because I really believe that in a symposium like this, unfortunately, we have to stick to the topic that they offer us, that they give us, and which I believe the audience also comes to hear. So, in the second round, I hope GÃ³ngora will give us a version more closely aligned with the topic we have proposed, if that is not too difficult a task. The next intervention will be by Jorge Alberto Manrique.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

13:39

The question about models of art in Latin America is undoubtedly related to yesterdayâs roundtable questions, about whether Latin American art exists as a distinguishable entity, and to those from yesterday and today in the literature roundtables, especially concerning the problem and function of criticism.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

14:22

To give meaning to my answer, I have to refer to what I believe is perhaps the characteristic that historically most defines Latin American culture.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

14:43

To respond or to give meaning to my response, I have to refer to the characteristic that, in my view, has most defined and historically defines Latin American culture. Perhaps even more, I would say, than the much-discussed, always problematic, and always debatable concept of mestizaje.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

15:14

The characteristic Iâm referring to is the need that our cultureâand we, as individuals and as a groupâhave, a need that, in my view, is expressed in a much sharper and deeper way than in other cultural spheres. This need to account for oneself, to explain oneself to oneself and to others, to explain oneself to what is other. I would even say that the endeavor which, in practice, responds to this need is perhaps the greatest contribution that Latin American culture has made in many fields to culture in generalâa topic, of course, that would belong to another symposium, not this one.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

16:32

Well, this is the case, as I understand it, because of Latin America's marginal and eccentric position in relation to what we call the West. In saying this, I am even referring to social and economic phenomena, to colonialism, to exploitation, to all those references one might wish to make, which I do not state explicitly because it is not entirely my intention nor perhaps the subject at hand.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

17:10

I do think itâs important to insist on the following: the eccentric situation is not necessarilyâat least in cultural terms, or perhaps only in cultural termsânot necessarily expressed in terms of inferiority, it is not necessarily one of inferiority, but it is one of ambiguity. Being Latin American is expressed through an ambiguity that I would call consubstantialâan ambiguity that is a being and not being, a belonging and not belonging to Europe, and that can be resolved in two ways. Two contradictory ways that depend on that essential structure.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

18:02

One [horn of the dilemma] lies in shortening distances. In the right that any Latin American has to say, 'I am a man like any other man. I am a man like everyone else and I can dedicate myself to the endeavors that any other man in any other part of the world pursues.' On the other hand, the other horn of the dilemma is resolved through the contradiction of placing distance between that Western model and this diffuse Latin American identity, by presenting oneself as peculiar, as different, in the also urgent need to assert oneself as something through difference and not through identity.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

18:57

Both alternative or simultaneous positions have occurred with more or less intensity in, I believe, all of our countries. I want to emphasize that, for me, both are equally valid and legitimate. The models that depend on these attitudesâgeneral cultural attitudesâthe models that operate in the visual arts field, are obviously, consequently, either 'Western' in quotation marks or 'native' in quotation marks, depending on the stance the artist takes. In general, they are always a combination of both positions, with just a stronger emphasis on one or the other.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

19:55

Lastly, I want to say that what characterizes Latin American art is the fact that, more strongly than in other contexts, producing art is a way of responding to oneâs circumstances. It is not the same to create geometric art that is hardly distinguishable from what is produced in Paris, New York, or London, as it is to seek a local meaning with significant expression.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

20:40

Geometrism, just to give an example â the geometrism produced in a Latin American country has, by that very fact, a different meaning. It is offering an explanation of Latin American reality and thus takes on a different meaning than a similar artistic expression created in any of the model capitals of the West. For now, I think thatâs all I can say. Until next time.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016

21:22

Weâll leave that for a later discussion. Iâd like to give the floor to Alejandro Otero

People
Mondrian, Piet, 1872-1944
Malevich, Kazimir Severinovich, 1878-1935
Tatlin, Vladimir Evgrafovich, 1885-1953

26:21

The first is the old but always renewable scholastic argument between the universal and the particular. Mondrian wished to carry modern art into an abstract realm that knew no national boundaries, that was indeed universal. The ambitious expatriates of Paris, on the other hand, weren't averse to confecting something particular which came to be known as the School of Paris. Malevich, in the exciting months before and after the Russian Revolution, soared into his suprematist vision of universality, while his rival Tatlin addressed himself to a particular revolution and the particular needs of what he hoped was a radically-changed society.Â 

People
Mindlin, JosÃ© E.

28:09

If the circumstances are harsh enough, repressive enough, as Mr. Mindlin said this morning, in fact intolerable, artists respond, they rebel, like anyone else. This was true during the Depression in the United States, during the popular front days in England and Paris, and for us during the Vietnam War.Â

El primero es el antiguo pero siempre renovable argumento escolÃ¡stico entre lo universal y lo particular. Mondrian deseaba llevar el arte moderno a un Ã¡mbito abstracto que no conociera fronteras nacionales, que fuera verdaderamente universal. This seems undeniable to me, but every time we try to prove how Western we are, we encounter a flaw, a lack. We are not that Western, or we are not Western in exactly the same way as the model that is proposed to us.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

08:02

So, this situation of ambiguity â itâs what constitutes us â but the fact is that, for me, this is not a flaw. It is neither a flaw nor a virtue.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

08:34

Paz, Octavio, 1914-1998

09:44

To begin with, I believe the same thing that Paz said yesterday regarding literary criticism. I believe there are undoubtedly critiques. There is no lack of them. However, it seems clear or evident to me that our circumstance is more of a testimonial criticism, I would call it, than a criticism that acts in the short term.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

10:22

This would indeed be a notable and circumstantial difference. That is, it is not a criticism that functions in the short term to the extent that criticism usually does, especially journalistic criticism, in the major centers of production of both art and criticism. This is its lack and perhaps that is its quality. This frees criticism in Latin America from commitments, even bribes, which are perhaps more common elsewhere than in our media.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

10:58

Now then. Sorry, but it does not exist to the extent it does in other places.

People
Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

11:35

It is normal that they seek it and even that they have to go look for it in the very place where it is produced; that is, the phenomenon of the Latin American artist exiled, temporarily or definitively, to which reference has already been made here.

Not a judge at any moment. On this, I obviously agree with Dore Ashton.

Manrique, Jorge Alberto, 1936-2016 (man)

People

07:57

Referring to what Manuel also spoke aboutâuniversalityâwhich has been discussed in this panel, I believe that the universal is nothing more than a way of provoking, of generating what Alazraqui this morning called 'generating reality'. When that provocation of reality truly reaches others, thatâs when we talk about the universal. Being universal is not something a painter or writer can freely chooseâit is beyond their control. Universality also has nothing to do with the dissemination or acceptance of the work.

Just a clarification: I believe that a critic never, in any way, establishes a model a priori, but a posteriori, from the artistâs work. The only ones capable of creating models are the artists, not the critics. Critics, at least in my opinion, what we must do is form a kind of bloc through the relationships between some similar artists, and from those relationships establish certain guidelines. But the modelâwhich could be mine, the model of resistanceâis not something Iâve made for artists to follow. Rather, the artists have shown me what their resistant attitude is and how I can group them together. Thatâs all.

People
Le Parc, Julio, 1928-

19:24

Then comes May â68, and Julio Le Parc gets excited about the student revolution, the revolt. He gets caught in a car while distributing pamphlets, is detained for two or three days, and has to leave for Spainâwhere he triumphantly returns two months later without any problems. In short, the man is definitively converted to the left, which I think is very good. He was invited to CubaâI met up with him in 1970 in Cuba. People
Le Parc, Julio, 1928-
Cuba

20:01

Le Parc returns to Paris; heâs offered to stay in Cuba but does not accept. He has every right not to, and I donât blame him. Once back, he surprisingly begins to produce completely flat, geometric worksâalmost like printed onesâlarge waves of aggressive colors. Being a renowned artist, he doesnât lose his place at the Denise RenÃ© gallery, keeps selling those works, and continues to exhibit worldwide, living off his past fame.

People
Le Parc, Julio, 1928-

20:31

And now he takes refuge in forms that seem more archaic in the history of geometry and kineticism. These are the questions I pose to my peers, to see if together we can solve this enigma. Thatâs all.
